s1: Society relies on many complex systems of interacting technology, people, processes, laws and other elements. Examples of such systems include air transport, telecommunications and energy supply.
s2: Networked Information Systems (NISs) are becoming an essential part of everyday experiences, in our kitchen appliances, cars, and public transport and for Internet banking and shopping.

s1: Systems Engineering is a holistic, multi-disciplinary and well established approach to the engineering of these complex systems.
s2: Discuss how network applications and their components work in real-life socio-economic, ethical, and legal contexts and evaluate their risks.

s1: Because software is a critical component of such systems, Software Engineers will often work in Systems Engineering teams.
s2: Discuss how network applications and their components work in real-life socio-economic, ethical, and legal contexts and evaluate their risks.
Analyse the role of network standards, protocols, and layered models.

s1: The Systems Engineering life-cycle and processes.
s2: Apply network design principles, topologies, architectures, and their components.

s1: Conceptual system design: including problem definition, technical performance measures, quality function deployment (QFD), trade-off analyses, and system specification.
s2: Apply network design principles, topologies, architectures, and their components.

s1: Preliminary system design: subsystem design requirements, design review.
s2: Apply network design principles, topologies, architectures, and their components.

s2: You will have the foundational basis to understand, evaluate, and compare new technologies and their applications.

s1: Students will also improve their ability to communicate with the multi-disciplinary engineering team and the community at large.
s2: In this course, you will learn fundamental concepts of data communication and networking in addition to gaining a working knowledge of network scalability, mobility, security, and managing capabilities.
